DIV1.P: A DISCOURSE ON THE Transcendent Glory OF THE GOSPEL. Deliver'd at the Lecture in Hingham.
By Ebenezer Gay, M. A. Pastor of a CHURCH there.

Q.P: The Glory of this latter House shall be greater than of the former, saith the Lord of hosts.

Even the mystery which hath been hid from Ages, and from Generations, but now is made manifest to his Saints, to whom God would make known what is the Riches of the Glory of this mystery among the Gentiles, which is Christ in you, the Hope of Glory.

DIV1.P: BOSTON in New-England: Printed for D. HENCHMAN, over against the Brick Meeting-House in Cornhil. MDCCXXVIII.

DIV1.HEAD: To the People of my Charge.

OPENER.SALUTE: Dearly Beloved in our Lord Jesus Christ,

DIV1.P:
IT was very pleasing unto me, to observe so ge∣neral a Desire amongst you, that a Monthly-Lecture might be preached in this Town: I was glad when ye said unto me, let us go into the house of the Lord. And your Attendence of such a religious Exercise, hath been hitherto un∣common and exemplary. I hope that you find God∣liness to be profitable for all things, having the pro∣mise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come. It is at the Request of many of you, and with an aim at the Good of all your Souls, that these Discourses are made so public. I am very sen∣sible, that they are far below the dignity of the Sub∣jects treated of; and if they shou'd (as most probably they will in this critical Age) be censured as weak and mean, I shall not blame any for being of my Opi∣nion: But I trust that you, to whom these Sermons were acceptable when preached, will read them with Candor, and a suitable concern that ye may be edi∣fied thereby. I send them abroad in a plain Country-Dress, it being such as I could afford them, and which will be most agreable to those on whom I de∣pend to give them Entertainment. You receive them from the Press, in the same words that you had them from the Pulpit. — The seasonableness of these Discourses, cannot (I think) be justly excepted against. The Contempt of the glorious Gospel is doubtless the most provoking Evil of the Times, and is comprehen∣sive of all those Sins, for which the righteous GOD hath a Controversy with our Land: An Essay there∣fore to raise in us due Tho'ts of the Excellency of the Gospel, will not be judged needless. While we are contemplating & adoring the Glory of GOD, which he hath discover'd in his late remarkable & amazing works of Providence, we shou'd not over-look, nor be unaffected with that brighter Display of it, which there is in the Gospel. GOD's saving manifestation of himself, is not to be expected in his providential
Dispensations, ordinary or extraordinary, nor in the Terrors of the Law, but in the Glass of his Gospel. The Lord was not in the wind, nor in the earthquake, nor in the fire, but in the still small voice, 1 Kin. 19.11, 12.

THE Voice of GOD, which is full of majesty, from the deep places of the Earth, hath awaken'd many to give the more earnest Heed to his sweet & gracious Voice, speaking from Heaven in the Gospel of CHRIST; and by the latter more than the former, is their Con∣version (which we hope is real) effected. There are many excellent Sermons lately publish'd, to teach & ex∣cite us rightly to consider & improve the terrible Works of GOD: and a Discourse concerning the Glory of the Gospel, may also, by the divine Blessing, serve to promote the Reformation, which is so earnestly prayed & la∣bour'd for.—Altho', to our shame & sorrow it must be said, there hath not been that noise & shaking among the dry bones here, which there hath been in other places under the late awful Dispensations, yet some (I hope) have been awakened to flee from wrath: and that they might continue to run well, and not look back, I have put them in remembrance of Lot's Wife.
THESE Sermons I dedicate unto you, my beloved People, and wish they might be profitable to your Souls, for which I will very gladly spend, and be spent.

I rejoyce in the Lord, that your Care of me hath flourished, in the provision ye have made for my out∣ward Support, ever since I have been in the work of the Ministry amongst you. And I speak it to your praise, that I have not been necessitated to ask for any mainte∣nance; but what ye have done towards it, ye have done of your own accord, as sensible that a Minister is not to live on the Alms of his People, but that the La∣bourer is worthy of his Hire. —There is one thing I need, and do now ask of you, to wit, Your more fer∣vent Prayers unto GOD for me, that he would make me an able and faithful Minister of the New Testa∣ment; and that after I have preached to you in Christ's Name, I may not (as there is great danger that I shall) perish eternally in his wrath. — Brethren pray for me, that the Word of the Lord may have free Course amongst us, and be glorified.

DIV1.HEAD: THE Transcendent Glory OF THE GOSPEL Displayed.

Q.P: FOR even that which was made Glorious, had no Glory in this respect, by reason of the Glory that excelleth.

DIV1.P:
THE Sovereignty and Power of divine Grace were marvellously display'd in the Conversion of Paul, who before was a furious Persecutor of the Church of Christ. And the Grace of God which was bestowed on him, was not in vain; for He laboured more abundantly than all his Fellow-workers unto the Kingdom. And GOD highly honoured Him, in propagating & promoting Christianity in the World, more by his Ministry than any other Man's. The shining Gifts & extraordinary Success of this great Apo∣stle, drew upon him the envious Hatred of false Teach∣ers; who maliciously endeavour'd to blast his Repu∣tation, and obstruct his Usefulness. This oblig'd him to speak much in his own vindication: which He did,
not out of Arrogance and Ostentation, but a sincere respect to the Glory of GOD, and the Good of the Church. Do we begin again (saith he in the first verse of this Chapter) to commend our selves? or need we as some others, Epistles of commendation to you, or Letters of commendation from you. The Apostle speaks in the plural Number, because He wrote not only in his own, but also in Timothy's Name to the Corinthians. He had begun again in the preceding Chapter to commend himself, by declaring his faith∣fulness, as he had done in his first Epistle to them. But here he seems to Check himself for it; and tells them, that he needed, not as others (meaning false Apostles & Teachers) commendatory Letters to them or from them: For they themselves, in regard of the Success of his Ministry amongst them, were a living Epistle, that might sufficiently recommend him to them, and to all other Churches. Ye are our Epistle written in our hearts, known and read of all men. As if he had said, You that have been Converted by my preaching, are a commendatory Epistle, which I carry about in my heart, having always a thankful and dear Remembrance of you, and which may satisfy all that have heard of your Faith and Obedience, that I am a true Apostle and faithful Minister of JESUS CHRIST. And he thus strongly proves that they were such an Epistle. Forasmuch as ye are manifestly de∣clared to be the Epistle of Christ ministred by us, written not with Ink, but with the Spirit of the living GOD, not in Tables of stone, but in fleshly Tables of the heart. Their holy Conversation declar'd them to be the Epistle of CHRIST. By them CHRIST sig∣nified his Mind and Will to others, as a Man doth his by a Letter. They were a living Rule, shewing by their Actions how all ought to walk. JESUS CHRIST with his Spirit, that accompanied the Apostle's Mini∣stry, did make saving Impressions on their Hearts; wrote his Law, not on Tables of Stone, but fleshly Tables, the Hearts of Believers. And such Trust have we through Christ to God-ward. The Apostle was humbly confident, that GOD had thus blessed
his Ministry to them. Not that we are sufficient of our selves to think any thing as of our selves: but our sufficiency is of God. Paul acknowledgeth that He was so far from being the Author of the good Work in the Corinthian Christians, that He could not of himself so much as think. A Man cannot think any thing without the Influence of divine Providence, and he cannot think a good Thought without the Influ∣ence of divine Grace. Every Act is from GOD, as he is the GOD of Nature, and the Goodness of any Act is from Him, as He is the GOD of all Grace. The Apostle was very careful not to exalt himself, when he was magnifying his Office. Our sufficiency (saith he) is of GOD: who also hath made us able Ministers of the New Testament. i. e. The Gospel, called a Testament, because it is a free & firm Dis∣position of the Mediator's good things unto the Heirs of Salvation, to be possessed by them according to his Will; and the New Testament, in regard of the an∣cient Promises of those good things under the Law. The Apostle having thus ascribed unto GOD, the Praise of all his Ability for and Success in the Work of the Ministry, He proves the Dignity of his Office by drawing a Comparison between the Law and the Gospel, and shewing how the latter did exceed the former in Glory. By several Arguments he de∣monstrates the surpassing Excellency of the Gospel; and in our Text declares that the Law, altho' glori∣ous in it self, and the manner of it's delivery, yet compar'd with the Gospel, hath no Glory at all: like as the Glory of the Stars disappears at the rising of the Sun. For even that which was made glo∣rious, had no glory in this respect, by reason of the glory that excelleth.
THE DOCTRINE from the Words is this, viz.

DIV2.HEAD: DOCTRINE, THAT the Gospel is incomparably more glo∣rious than the Law.
DIV2.P: BY the Law, we may understand the Revelation which GOD made of himself, his Mind & Will before the coming of CHRIST in the flesh; and by the Gospel, the Revelation which GOD hath granted since that Time: The former is contain'd in the Scriptures usually stiled the Old Testament, the latter in those of the New. By the Law is sometimes meant the De∣calogue only, or ten Commandments, called the moral Law; sometimes the Ceremonial Institutions, the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances; sometimes all the Scriptures of the Old Testament, the Writings of Moses and the Prophets. The Law, taken in either of these Senses, hath comparatively no Glory, in respect of the Glory of the Gospel that excel∣leth. The Law is in our Context, said to be glorious, and the Gospel is stiled the glorious Gospel, 2 Cor. 4.4. The Law is in the verse preceding our Text, called Glory it self and the Gospel is so termed, 1 Thes. 2.12. But altho' the Law be very excellent and glorious, yet the Gospel far exceedeth it in Glory. Compar'd with the Glory of the Gospel, the Law hath none.
WHEREIN, and how far the Gospel exceeds the Law in Glory, is now to be consider'd by us.
I. THE Gospel is more Glorious than the Law, in regard of the first Publisher of it.

THE Law is, in our Text, said to be that, which was made Glorious: Besides it's intrinsick Glory, there was some additional Glory made to it, by GOD'S sending of it to his People, by the hand of so excellent a Person, as He did: But the Glory which the Gos∣pel hath in respect of the transcendent Dignity of the Lord's Messenger, who first published it, far exceedeth that. The Law was given by Moses, but Grace and Truth (i. e. the Gospel, called Grace in opposition to the Severity of the Law, and Truth in opposition to the Types and Shadows of the legal Dispensation) came by Jesus Christ, Joh. 1.17. Moses, whom GOD employed to deliver the Law to his an∣cient People, was a glorious Saint and extraordinary
Prophet: but the Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the Gos∣pel at first began to be spoken, did infinitely excel Him. The Messiah was promised of old, as a Pro∣phet like unto Moses, Deut. 18.15. He did in many respects signally resemble Moses: but this don't im∣ply that he was not in all superior to him. CHRIST was not only like to Moses in Moses's chiefest Excel∣lencies, but He also infinitely surpassed him. Heb. 3.3. This Man was counted worthy of more glory than Moses. Moses was but a Man, Christ was GOD as well as Man: Moses was not without Sin, but Christ was holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from Sinners: Moses was only a Servant, Christ was also the Son of GOD. When Moses came down from Mount Sinai, bringing the two Tables of Testimony, his Face shone with a dazling Glory, Exod. 34.30. When Aaron and all the Children of Israel saw Moses, behold, the skin of his Face shone, and they were afraid to come nigh him. This is mention'd in our Context, v. 7. as one thing which made the Law glorious; The mi∣nistration of Death written and ingraven in stones, was glorious, so that the Children of Israel could not stedfastly behold the Face of Moses, for the Glory of his Countenance. The Lustre spread on the Face of Moses, was an evidence to the Jews, of the GOD of Glory's sending him to publish the Law unto them. But Jesus Christ far excel'd Moses in the visible Glory wherewith his Face did shine, when GOD, by a voice from Heaven, declar'd him to be his Son, by whom he would speak, and unto whom Men shou'd hearken. Moses in all his Glory, was not arrayed with such Splendor as Christ was, at his solemn Investiture into his Office. When Jesus was baptized, Heaven was opened to pour down it's Glory on him: and the holy Ghost descended in a bodily shape, like a Dove upon him, Luk. 3.21, 22. The holy Ghost is incor∣poreal, but he then assumed a bodily visible Shape, and doubtless one that was very bright and glorious. Some think, that it cannot be concluded from what the Scripture saith concerning the holy Ghost's De∣scent on Christ, that he appeared in the form of a Dove:
But suppose that he assum'd a Body of Light, or Fire, and therein came down, in such like manner as a Dove, with it's Wings spread forth, and gathering about our SAVIOUR'S Head cover'd and crown'd it with a visibly Glory. But why may we not, according to the Letter of the Scripture, conceive that the bodily Shape in which the holy Ghost descended on Christ, was that of a Dove, intimating the Dove-like Dispo∣sition of the harmless JESUS? And yet, we have reason to believe that it was in some luminous form, some extraordinary appearance of Light, that the holy Ghost came down on our Saviour. Justin Martyr speaking of Christ's Baptism saith, that there was a Fire lighted in the River Jordan. "By which it appears, that it was an early Tradition in the Church, that the Water, immediately after Christ was baptized in it, seem'd to be all on Fire by the Reflection of that bright and flaming appearance, in which the holy Ghost descended upon him". And at his Trans∣figuration on Mount Tabor, His Face did shine as the Sun, and his Raiment was white as the Light, Mat. 27.2. His Face did shine as the Sun in it's meridian Brightness, and his Raiment was like the whitness of a flash of Lightning. The three Disciples that were with Christ on the Mount, were afraid and astonished at the sight, as Aaron and the Israelites were at the sight of the Glory on Moses's Face. The Honour and Glory which Christ received from GOD the Father, at his Baptism and Transfiguration, was too great to be communicated to any but the Son of GOD; It was therefore the Sign, by which John the Baptist knew him to be the true Messiah; and upon which he groun∣ded his Testimony concerning him, Joh. 1.33, 34. I know him not: but he that sent me to baptize with water; the same said unto me, upon whom thou shalt see he Spirit descending and remaining on him, the same which baptizeth with the holy Ghost. And I sa & record that this is the Son of God. The visible Splendor with which Christ was invested at his Baptism and Transfiguration, was so great, that all who beheld it might rationally conclude that he was
the Son of GOD: Such Glory wou'd not be imparted to any other. John the Evangelist, who was an Eye∣witness of the Glory shed on Christ at his Transfigu∣ration, and probably of that at his Baptism also, doth partly with reference thereunto say, Joh. 1.14. We beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father. The Glory was such as became him, who was the only begotten Son of GOD: It was questionless therefore a Glory far surpassing that on the Face of Moses, when he brought down the Law from Sinai. Jesus Christ must be infinitely more glorious than Moses, being the Brightness of God's glory, and the express Image of his Person, Heb. 1.3. In him dwelt all the fulness of the infinite Godhead bodily, and from him did it shine forth in the Days of his Flesh, he being the Effulgence of his Father's Glory. Moses was not more than a Prophet, John the Bap∣tist was, and among them that are born of Women, there arose not a greater than John; yet he counted himself not worthy to do the meannest Office for CHRIST, to be the least and lowest of his Attendants, Luke 3.16. —One mightier than I cometh, the latchet of whose Shoes I am not worthy to unloose.
THUS, in respect of the Glory which the Law and Gospel receive from the shining Excellencies of the first Publishers thereof, the latter doth abundantly exceed the former in Glory.
II. THE Gospel is more glorious than the Law in regard of the Circumstances which attended the Promulgation of it.

THE Law was made glorious by the manner of it's delivery. When the LORD came down on Mount Sinai, holy Angels were the Chariots of his Glory, He rode upon Cherubims, and there was an illustri∣ous Appearance of Myriads of them, Psal. 68.17. The Chariots of God are twenty thousand, even thou∣sands of Angels: the Lord is among them as in Sinai, in the holy place. The Mount was altogether on a smoke, because the LORD descended upon it in Fire: and the smoke thereof ascended as the smoke of a Fur∣nace,
and the whole Mount quaked greatly: Sinai was moved at the Presence of the GOD of Israel. There was the sound of a Trumpet, long and loud; the noise of Thunders, and the voice of Words, very ter∣rifying. The glorious manner in which GOD gave the Law on Sinai, is elegantly set forth by the Pro∣phet, Hab. 3.3, 4. GOD came from Teman, and the holy One from Mount Paran, Selah. His Glory covered the Heavens, and the Earth was full of his Praise, or Splendor. And his brightness was as the light, he had horns, or bright Beams, coming out of his hand: "Rays of Glory were darted forth around Him" With such Tokens of Majesty was the Pro∣mulgation of the Law attended. But, altho' there was less Terror, yet there was not less Glory in the Circumstances which accompanied the first Publication of the Gospel. It was usher'd in, by Angel's decla∣ring and celebrating the Birth of JESUS, that Horn of Salvation which GOD promis'd to raise up unto his People, in the House of his Servant David. The poor Shepherds at Bethlehem, saw as great Glory there, and as bright an Apparition of Angels, as the Israelites did at Sinai, and heard more glorious Words, Luke 2.9, 10, 11. Lo, the Angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them; and they were sore afraid. And the Angel said unto them, fear not, for behold, I bring you good tydings of great Joy, which shall be to all people, for unto you is born this day in the city of David, a Saviour; which is Christ the Lord. ver. 13, 14. And suddenly there was with the Angel, a multitude of the heavenly host, praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on Earth peace, good will towards Men. — A glorious Lamp was lighted in the aetherial Heaven, an extraordinary Star appeared, to give notice to the World of the Ap∣proach of the Sun of Righteousness, Matth. 2.1, 2. Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea, in the days of Herod the king: behold, there came wise men from the East to Jerusalem, saying, where is He that is born king of the Jews? for we have seen his Star in the East, and are come to worship
him. — Was there not more Glory deriv'd on the Gospel, from what was done and said at Christ's Baptism and Transfiguration, than there was on the Law, from all that Majesty and awful Pomp that Mount Sinai was cover'd with? What a glorious Scene was it, for Heaven to open, and the holy Ghost visibly to descend on Christ to array Him with a daz∣ling Splendor, and such a voice to come from the excellent Glory, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased, hear ye Him? Was there any Brightness at Sinai, comparable to that on Mount Tabor? or any Voice so glorious? — And in order to the more full and extensive Publication of the Gos∣pel, by the Apostles of Christ, the Descent of the holy Ghost upon them, at the Feast of Pentecost (the same time of the Year, that the Law was given at Sinai) was a thing which equal'd, if not exceeded in glory, any Circumstance which attended the Pro∣mulgation of the Law. There was indeed no Trum∣pet, nor terrifying Voice, no Thunder, Darkness nor Tempest, but a sound from Heaven, as of a rushing mighty Wind, and it filled all the House where the Apostles were sitting; and there was the Appearance of bright flames of Fire, cleaving asunder; and in the form of Tongues resting on the Heads of the Disci∣ples, and they spake all Languages to the astonish∣ment of multitudes who were then present, Act. 2. So that the publication of the Gospel was graced with as remarkable and glorious Circumstances, as that of the Law. It might also, under this Head, be shown, How the Miracles which attended the publication of the Gospel, thro' Christ's and his Apostle's time on Earth, did, both in number and greatness, far exceed those which accompanied the Promulgation of the Law. Moses and the Prophets did not, all of them do, so many, nor such mighty Works, as JESUS of Nazareth did. How great must that Salvation be, how glorious that Gospel, which at first began to be spoken, and was thus proved by the Lord, and was afterwards confirmed likewise by them that heard him; GOD bearing them witness, both with Signs and Wonders,
and with diverse Miracles, and gifts of the holy Ghost, according to his will?
III. THE Gospel is more glorious than the Law, in respect of its revealing the Glory of GOD so much more clearly and fully, than the Law doth.
Particularly,
1. THE Glory of divine Mercy shining in the Face of Jesus Christ, it clearly displayed by the Gospel.

GOD'S Goodness is his Glory; and this is most clearly and fully revealed in the Gospel; the sum of which is, that God is in Christ, reconciling the World unto himself, not imputing their Trespasses unto them. The moral Law discovers nothing of GOD'S Mercy toward sinful Creatures: and the ceremonial Law had only a shadow of good things to come, and not the very Image of the things: It contain'd a dark and imperfect, not a lively and full Representation of those good things, which the Mercy of GOD designed for miserable Sinners. The Mystery of Christ, which the Gospel reveals, was under the legal Dispensa∣tion wrapped up in Types, Ceremonies, and obscure Prophesies and Promises. The Gospel, the Preaching of Jesus Christ is the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret since the world began, Rom. 16.25. The Riches of Grace, the unsearchable Riches of Christ were, in a great measure hid, before the Gospel open'd them; so that as the Prophet, and after him, the Apostle said concerning the same, Eye had not seen, nor Ear heard, neither had entred into the Heart of Man, the things which God hath prepared for them that Love him.
2. THE Glory of divine Wisdom, shining in the face of Jesus Christ is eminently displayed in the Gospel.

WHEN the Bowels of GOD'S Mercy were troubled for us, the Mouth of his Justice was opened against us miserable Sinners. Justice demanded the ever∣lasting
Destruction of Guilty, and therefore defer∣vedly accursed Creatures; and back'd it's Demand with powerful Arguments, taken from the Holiness of GOD, and his Veracity in his Threatnings: And Mercy's Pleas for the Salvation of the miserable Chil∣dren of Men, were so importunate, that GOD would not reject them. Therefore he employ'd his infinite Wisdom in the Counsel of Peace between the Father and the Son, to contrive a Method of Redemption, in which these Attributes shou'd harmonize, Justice and Mercy kiss each other, and be glorified together. And this adorable Wisdom the Gospel reveals; Wisdom, which was before hidden, 1 Cor. 2.7. Wis∣dom, which the blessed Angels discover'd nothing of by their immediate Views of the divine Glory in Heaven; They always behold the Face of GOD, yet they saw not this Wisdom till the Gospel exhibited the Face of Jesus Christ. Eph. 3.10. To the intent that now unto the Principalities & Powers in heavenly places, might be known by the church the manifold Wisdom of God.

THUS the Glory of GOD, especially the Glory of his Mercy & Wisdom is most clearly discover'd in the Gospel, Joh. 1.18. No man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten Son which is in the bosom of the Father; he hath declared him. The Bosom is the Seat of Love, and Repository of Secrets: Jesus Christ who is in the bosom of God the Father, hath by the Gospel made known his tender Compassions and my∣sterious Counsels. The Gospel being such a Reve∣lation, the Glory of it far surpasseth that of the Law
IV. THE Gospel exceeds the Law in glory, in∣asmuch as it is a general Revelation, designed for the use and benefit of mankind.

AS it is a clearer and more compleat Revelation of GOD, his Mind and Will, so it is intended and granted for the Instruction and Advantage of more than the Law was. The Law was a Revelation directed to the Jews peculiarly, and not vouchsafed to other
Nations, Psal. 147.19, 20. He sheweth his word unto Jacob, his statutes and his Judgments unto Israel. He hath not dealt so with any Nation: and as for his Judgments, they have not known them. The Legal Despensation was restrained to that People, whom the LORD Chose to be a special People unto himself, above all that were upon the face of the Earth. To the Israelites pertained the Adoption, and the Glory, and the Covenants, and the giving of the Law, and the service of GOD, and the 'Promises, Rom. 9.4. The Law of Commandments contained in Ordi∣nances was a Wall of Partition, that fenced the Jewish Nation, and sever'd, them from others, making them GOD'S Sacred Inclosure, into which the Gentiles should not come, to partake of the Privileges of the Church. The Ceremonial Law is stiled the Enmity, being the cause and sign of Enmity between Jews and Gentiles, keeping them at a distance from one another. Thus the Law was confined within nar∣row Bounds; was directed and restrained to the Use of one Nation, and that the fewest of all People. But the Gospel is a Dispensation, in it's Nature, and in it's Author's Design, general: or such as respects Mankind, without any distinction of Nation. There is no Monopoly of it's Privileges. It is proportion'd to the need, and ordain'd for the benefit of Men of all Nations and Conditions. The Gospel is (as the angelical Preacher said) Good tydings of great Joy, which shall be to all people, Luke 2.10. The Grace of God, i.e. The Gospel that bringeth Salvation, hath appeared to all Men, Tit. 2.11. Christ hath broken down the middle wall of partition between Jews and Gentiles; Having abolished in his flesh the enmity, even the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances: and came and preached Peace, i. e. The Gospel of Peace, to them which were afar off, and to them that were nigh. The Gentiles therefore are no more Strangers and Foreigners, but fellow Citizens with the Saints and of the houshold of God, Eph. 2. Now a general Revelation intended and granted for the benefit of all, is more glorious than that which was particular, or restrained to one People.
That Glory excelleth, which is not only in it self brighter, but also in it's extent spread further, than another Glory; and such is the Glory of the Gospel, compar'd with that of the Law. The Law was as a Lamp which illuminates one Room: The Gospel is as the Sun, whose going forth is from one end of the Heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it, diffu∣sing a universal Light. And surely the glory of the Sun, in this respect, far surpasseth that of a burning Lamp, and as much doth the Glory of the Gospel that of the Law.
V. THE Gospel is more glorious than the Law, because it is the ministration of the Spirit.

THE Gospel is in opposition to the Law, called the Spirit, and the ministration of the Spirit, Con∣text, ver. 6.8. Because the Spirit of GOD accompanies the Dispensation of it, much more than it did that of the Law. By means of the Gospel Persons receive the holy Spirit; Gal. 3.2. This only would I learn of you, received ye the Spirit by the works of the Law, or by the hearing of Faith? By the works of the Law, we are here to understand the doctrine of Justification by the Works of the Law, which the Judazing Teachers preached: and by the hearing of Faith, is meant the Doctrine of the Gospel; hearing being put for the thing heard, and Faith for the Doctrine believed: By the hearing of Faith, and not by the Works of the Law is the Spirit received. It is true, that under the Law GOD bestowed his Spirit on his Servants, Neh. 9.20. Thou gavest also thy good Spi∣rit, to instruct them. But the holy Spirit is more plentifully granted under the Evangelical, than it was under the Legal Dispensation. The gift of the Spirit, in the largest measures of it, was reserv'd for the Glory of Gospel-times. GOD often promised, that in the Day of Gospel-light he wou'd pour out his Spirit: This Phrase imports his bestowing of it plen∣tifully. It is with an eye to Gospel-times, that GOD'S giving his Spirit is express'd by his pouring of it forth. The Spirit was more sparingly given under the Law, than it is under the Gospel; It then came
down from Heaven, at it were, in a few drops, but now, as it were, in a full Stream. Under the Gos∣pel, that Promise, I will pour out my Spirit on all Flesh, is fulfill'd, Acts 2.16, 17. "There were some sprinklings of it under the law, and confin'd to a se∣parate Nation, but now showers are poured down upon all Nations, to make them fruitful in good Works". On this account the Gospel is far more glorious than the Law, as the Apostle argueth in our Context, Ver. 7, 8. If the ministration of death (i. e. the Law) written and ingraven in stones was glori∣ous — How shall not the ministration of the Spirit be rather glorious?
VI. THE Gospel is far more glorious than the Law, in regard of the wonderful Effects produced by it.

THE glorious Things which have been, and still are effected by the Gospel, accompanied with the Spirit of GOD, declare it's surpassing Glory.— I might here Instance in those great and marvellous things which were done by it in the World at the first Preach∣ing thereof, and in those also which it still per∣formeth in the Souls of Men; equal to which, in number, or Glory, were never accomplished by the Law.
1. THE Effects produced by the Gospel in the World, at the first Preaching of it, were admirable and glorious.

THE Blow that was given to Satan's visible King∣dom on Earth, by no other Weapon than the Gos∣pel, sheweth the Excellency of it; and may well make us to say concerning it, as David of the Sword with which he slew Goliah, There is none like it. The Rulers of the darkness of this World never had a more extensive Dominion, nor exercis'd a more Ty∣ranical Power over the miserable Children of Men, than about the time that the Gospel began to be preached. The Devil was then seated and strength∣ned in the Government of the Nations; was wor∣shipped as a God: He almost every where had his
Temples, Altars and Oracles, that were much fre∣quented and consulted. The People brought their Offerings unto him; he did eat the fat of Sacrifices, and drink the blood of drink-Offerings; yea the Blood of his cruel Votaries Sons & Daughters, whom they bar∣barously sacrificed unto him. Idolatry & Superstition every where prevailed. But by the Preaching of the Gospel, the Devil's Kingdom was shaken, and he lost that great Power which he before had in the World. Luke 10.17, 18. The seventy returned again with joy, saying, Lord, even the Devils are subject unto us, thro' thy name. And he said unto them, I be∣held Satan as Lightning fall from Heaven. Our Saviour in this Expression, might allude unto Satan's first Fall from Heaven; when of an Angel of Light he became a Spirit of Darkness, and was in a mo∣ment cast down from his glorious Seat in Heaven: So by the Preaching of the Gospel he shou'd be turn∣ed out of the Throne which he had usurped on Earth, and fall from his great Power in the World, as Light∣ning flasheth & vanisheth away suddenly & irrecovera∣bly. When the Gospel was first published by Christ, and Those sent by him immediately to preach it, the King∣dom of darkness was soon weakned, and did appa∣rently go to wreck. The Devil was beaten out of his Territories, his Temples were demolished, his Altars thrown down, and his Oracles silenced. With that Rod of his Strength which Christ sent out of Zion, he destroyed the Works of the Devil, 2 Cor. 10.4. The weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty thro' God, to the pulling down of strong Holds. The Apostles Warfare against Principalities and Powers was spiritual, the Weapons they used were not carnal, yet mighty thro' GOD: They atchie∣ved glorious Conquests, but not by the edge of the Sword, or stratagems of War: The Gospel was, thro' GOD the mighty and effectual Weapon, with which they batter'd the Devil's Fortresses, and over-turn'd his Dominion. The Gospel prevail'd against the Learning of Philosophers, and Power of Earthly Kings, and gloriously triumph'd over all the Opposition
which it met with from the Gates of Hell. Dagon fell before the Ark of GOD; and the Magicians Ser∣pents were devoured by Aaron's Rod; so the Gospel was too hard for all the Strength and Wisdom of the World. The Walls of Jericho fell down at the Priests blowing of the Rams Horns; so when the Trumpet of the Gospel was sounded by the Ministers thereof, down went the Images, Idolatries and Superstitions of the Gentiles, and the Religion of Christ took place, and his Kingdom was set up on the Ruin of Satan's. In a few Years the Gospel (like Leaven which soon leaveneth the whole Lump) spread into almost all parts of the known World. Col. 1.6. The Gospel is come unto you, as it is in all the World. The great Change wrought in the World, by means of the Gospel, at the first Preaching of it, speaks it glorious.
2. THE Effects which the Gospel still produceth in the Souls of Men are great ana glorious.
IN regard of those things especially, which the Gospel, accompanied with the holy Spirit, effecteth in the Souls of Believers, the Apostle doth in our Text and Context so magnify it above the Law.
1. THE Gospel worketh effectually to the Con∣version of Souls.

NOT only was Satan's visible Kingdom in the World marvellously destroy'd by the Gospel, at the first Preaching of it, but also his invisible Empire in the Hearts of Sinners is continually broken by this Rod of Christ's strength, which he hath sent out of Zion. This dasheth in pieces the Works of the De∣vil within Men, as powerfully as it did those with∣out them. The strong Holds which he hath erected in the Souls of Men, blindness of Mind, hardness of Heart, stubbornness of Will, and the like, are demo∣lished by the Gospel, as gloriously as were the false Religions, Idolatries and Superstitions, which he had set up in the World. Luke 11.21, 22. When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace. But when a stronger than he shall come upon him, and
overcome him, he taketh from him all his armour wherein he trusted, and divideth his spoil. Satan is the strong Man armed, the Heart of every uncon∣verted Sinner is his Garrison which he keeps shut up, and barred again CHRIST, by unreasonable Pre∣judices, carnal Inclinations and worldly Interests; but the King of Glory, by his Spirit in the Gospel, comes upon, and casts out the strong Man armed, storms and takes his Fort, and converteth it into a holy Temple. Upon the white Horse of the pure Word of Truth, the mighty Redeemer still rideth forth conquering, and to conquer, Rev. 6.2. By means of the Gospel Persons are turned from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God. The Gos∣pel, and not the Law, is the Instrumental Cause of saving Conversion, Cont. ver. 8. The Letter killeth, but the Spirit giveth life. The moral Law revealing Man's Duty, and denouncing GOD'S Wrath against Him for not performing it, killeth: It makes Sin to revive in the Conscience, and the guilty to dye. It only sheweth Sinners that they are dead Men, being condemned already; and discovers to them no possible way of escaping the Curse, and offers no Grace, no supernatural Strength unto them to enable them to get out of the State of Nature. But the Spirit giveth Life: The Gospel which is called the Spirit quickeneth those who are dead in Trespasses and Sins. Spiritual Life is infused by means of the Gospel: The holy Ghost useth it as his Instrument in quick∣ning of dead Souls, Converting of sinful Men, Joh. 5.25. Verily, verily I say unto you, the hour is coming, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God; and they that hear shall live. CHRIST'S voice in the Gospel raiseth the spiritually dead. The beginning and progress of Conversion is by means of the Gospel; the whole conformity of the Soul unto Christ is wrought thereby; as the Apostle sheweth in our Context, Ver. 18. We all with open face, beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same Image; from glory to glory, even as by the Spirit of the Lord. The fight of the
LORD'S Glory in the Glass of the Gospel, is trans∣forming; Changeth the Soul into the Image and like∣ness of CHRIST. The Spirit of GOD worketh a sa∣ving Change in the Heart of a Sinner, by giving him a clear view of CHRIST'S Glory, as the Gospel repre∣sents it. And the holy Ghost carries on the work of Sanctification in Believers, by enabling them to see more and more of the LORD'S Glory in that Glass: They are changed into his Image, from Glory to Glory; that is, from one degree of Grace to another, until they arrive to the perfection of Holiness. All the De∣grees of our conformity to CHRIST are stiled Glory; the first and lowest degree of Grace is Glory begun, and the highest is Glory perfected. Believers see the Glory of the Lord in the Gospel, and are changed into the same Image, from Glory to Glory; that is, (as one conceiveth from the allusion to a Glass) "The Glory of the Lord shining upon the Gospel, and from the Gospel shining upon our Hearts, doth Change them into the Image of the same Glory; even as the Glory of the Sun shining upon a Glass, and from that Glass reflecting on a Wall, doth therein produce an Image of it's own light." Thus it is by the Gospel that a saving Change is wrought in the Soul. This Glory is peculiar to the Gos∣pel. It is said indeed, that the Law of the Lord is perfect, converting the Soul, Psal. 19.7. But by the Law here, as in many other Texts of Scrip∣ture, is meant the whole Word of GOD, compre∣hending the Promises of Salvation by Christ. The mo∣ral Law is not the Instrumental Cause of Conversion. It prepares a Soul for Conversion, inasmuch as by it is the knowledge of Sin: It convinceth the Sinner of Guilt, and deserved Damnation, but leaves him shut up under the fearful Curse, without the least hope of escape. Did not the Gospel reveal that God was in Christ reconciling the world unto himself, the awa∣ken'd Sinner wou'd pine away in his Iniquities. It is not the Terror of the LORD, which in the Law, but his Glory shining in the Gospel, that pro∣duceth a saving Change in the Heart.
2. PEACE of Conscience is an excellent Effect of the Gospel.

BY Peace of Conscience, I mean that rest and com∣fort which the believing Soul enjoyeth in the expecta∣tion and perswasion of GOD'S Mercy thro' CHRIST, to pardon and save it. This is the product of the Gos∣pel of Peace. The Law is in our Context stiled the ministration of Condemnation, because it passeth the Sentence of Death upon the Transgressor of it, and gives Conscience it's Authority to condemn the Sinner: But the Gospel is called the ministration of Righteous∣ness, because it exhibits and offers a Righteousness suf∣ficient for our Justification: Therein is the Righte∣ousness of God revealed from faith to faith, Rom. 1.17. The Gospel revealing that perfect Righteousness, which GOD graciously imputeth without the Works of the Law, to those who believe in Christ, is the means of setling an happy Peace in the Conscience. Now, as the Apostle saith in the verse immediately preceding our Text, If the ministration of Condemna∣tion be glory, much more doth the ministration of Righteousness exceed in Glory. The Gospel far excels the Law in that it is the ministration of Righteousness, and so of Peace. It is true, there is some mention made of this Righteousness in the Writings of Moses and the Prophets; hence it is said, Rom. 3.21, 22. Now the Righteousness of God without the Law is manifested, being witnessed by the Law and the Pro∣phets; even the Righteousness of God which is by faith of Jesus Christ, unto all, and upon all them that believe. But by the Law here the Apostle doth not intend the moral Law, for that is wholly silent con∣cerning an imputed Righteousness: But he means the Law of Commandments contained in Ordinances, the ceremonial Law; and it is certain, that the Sacrifices under the Law did typify the Death of CHRIST, by which we have now received the Atonement; and there were also many Prophesies and Promises of Christ, as the Lord our Righteousness; and yet the glorious Mystery of Justification by Faith in Christ, was in a great measure kept secret until the Gospel mani∣fested
it. In the Tabernacle were offered both gifts and sacrifices, that could not make him that did the service perfect, as pertaining to the conscience, Heb. 9.9. They indeed prefigur'd a Sacrifice sufficient to pacify Wrath, and quiet Conscience, yet those Sacri∣fices, and also the Promises and Prophesies which the Old Testament Church enjoyed, were but an obscure exhibition of that Righteousness which is the founda∣tion of Pardon and Peace, Heb. 10.1. For the Law having a shadow of good things to come, and not the very image of the things, can never with those sacri∣fices, which they offered year by year continually, make the comers thereunto perfect. "The Jewish Ordinances were rather a Bond acknowledging the Debt, than an Acquittance shewing the Discharge; therefore called, The Hand-writing of Ordinances against us." But the Gospel clearly revealing the Righteousness of CHRIST for our Justification, ma∣keth those who receive it perfect as pertaining to the Conscience.
3. A glorious Liberty is another Effect of the Gospel.

THE glorious Liberty of the Children of GOD is spoken of, Rom. 8.21. It is by the Gospel that Men are made Partakers of it. Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is Liberty, Cont. v. 17. By the Liberty of the Children of GOD, we may understand such an ingenuous Disposition as that Men do look upon, and act towards GOD as a gracious Father, in and thro' JESUS CHRIST. The Law, the Covenant from Mount Sinai gendreth to Bondage, Gal. 4.24. Those who are under it, are in the Condition of Slaves, not of Sons. It produceth such a Temper and Spirit towards GOD, as Slaves usually have toward their Masters; being influenced to their Duty only by Fear, or an apprehension of the Severity of their Masters, and the smart of the Rod. But the Gospel produceth a Child-like Temper in the Souls of Be∣lievers. By it they receive, not the Spirit of bon∣dage again to fear, but the spirit of adoption, where∣by they cry, Abba, Father, Rom. 8.15. It gives a filial Freedom, so that Believers may come unto GOD
at all times, as Children to a Father: They may come to the Throne of Grace, in every time of need, with greater boldness, than the High-Priest under the Law could once a Year enter into the Holiest of all.
THUS the Gospel in regard of the Effects produced by it, is more glorious than the Law.
VII. THE Gospel is far more glorious than the Law in respect of the Duration of it.

THERE is verily a disannulling of the command∣ment going before, for the weakness and unprofitable∣ness thereof, Heb. 7.18. An end is put to the Legal Dispensation, but the Evangelical shall continue to the End of the World, Matth. 28.19, 20. Go ye there∣fore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name, of the Father, and of the Son, and of the holy Ghost: Teaching them to observe all things whatso∣ever I have commanded you: and lo, I am with you alway, even unto the End of the World. Had there been no defect in the Legal, GOD would not have introduc'd the Evangelical Dispensation: The Change is to the better: GOD will not alter or abrogate the present Dispensation, because there is not a better to succeed in the room of it, Heb. 12.26, 27. Whose voice then shook the Earth, but now he hath pro∣mised, saying, yet once more I shake not the Earth only, but also Heaven. And this word, yet once more, signifieth the removing of those things that are shaken, as of things that are made, that those things which cannot be shaken may remain. The LORD'S voice shook the Earth, when he deliver'd the Law at Sinai; the whole Mount quaked greatly: but he shook not the Earth only, but also Heaven, the Jewish Church-State, at the bringing in of the Gospel. And he removed the Types and Ordinances of the Law, as things never designed by him the Appointer and Founder of them, to continue always; and so made way for the Introduction & Establishment of the Gos∣pel and the Ordinances thereof, which are things that cannot be shaken, but shall remain to the End of the
World. The Gospel-state is that Kingdom which cannot be moved. The Angel which John saw fly∣ing in the midst of Heaven, (which might denote the speed and diligence of Christ's faithful Ambassa∣dors) had the everlasting Gospel to preach unto them that dwell on the Earth, Rev. 14.6. This proves the transcendent Excellency of the Gospel. For (as the Apostle saith in the verse following our Text) if that which was done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is glorious.
IN these respects the Gospel exceedeth the Law in Glory, and so far that even that which was made glo∣rious, had no Glory, in comparison of the Glory that excelleth.
HAVING thus Illustrated and Confirmed the Truth, I proceed to Apply it.
1. IS the Gospel so much more glorious than the Law? We may hence infer the great Dignity of the Evangelical Ministry.

IT is consistent with the Humility that shou'd cloath the Ministers of the lowly JESUS, to assert the Dig∣nity of their sacred Employment. The holy Apostle Paul, who counted himself less than the least of all Saints, is, in the Chapter wherein our Text is, mag∣nifying his Office; and he strongly proves it honou∣rable from the transcendent Glory of the Gospel. His genuine Inference from his large Discourse concerning the Excellency of the Gospel is that in Ver. 12, 13. Cont. Seeing then that we have such hope, we use great plainness of speech, and not as Moses, who put a vail over his face. As if he had said, The Gospel being in so many respects more glorious than the Law, and especially since, according to our certain Expecta∣tion, it shall continue to the End of the World, I am not ashamed of my ministration, but do thus boldly vindicate my Apostleship, and do not, as Moses vail the Glory which the LORD hath put upon me. The more excellent a divine Revelation is, the more noble
is their Office, who are sent with it to the Children of Men. It was glorious to be a Minister of the Law, it is much more so to be a Minister of the Gospel. John the Baptist, CHRIST'S Harbinger and Herald, was more than a Minister of the Law, more than a Prophet: The Law and the Prophets were until John: But in his Time Christ was actually exhibited, and he declar'd the Messiah to be already come, pointing him out, as it were with the Finger, saying, Behold the Lamb of GOD. So that John's Mini∣stry excel'd any that was before; yet when our Sa∣viour was speaking of John's greatness, he show'd that under the Evangelical Dispensation, when the Gospel shou'd be fully preached, the least Minister thereof wou'd, in respect of his Office, be greater than John, be a more honourable Officer than he, Matth. 11.11. Verily I say unto you, among them that are born of women, there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist: notwithstanding, he that is least in the Kingdom of Heaven, is greater than he. The more glorious a Kingdom is, the more honourable is an Office in it: The Gospel Kingdom is termed the Kingdom of Heaven; the Glory of it exceeds that of all the Kingdoms of this World: To be a Mini∣ster therefore of CHRIST'S spiritual Kingdom on Earth, is no mean Preferment. No Man taketh this Honour unto himself, without horrid Usurpation, but he that is called of GOD to this high and holy Office, shou'd be very humble and thankful; saying with the great Apostle Paul, Eph. 3.8. Unto me, who am less than the least of all Saints, is this Grace given, that I should preach among the Gentiles the unsearchable Riches of Christ: And, 1 Tim. 1.12. I thank Christ Jesus our Lord who hath enabled me, for that he counted me faithful, putting me into the Ministry.— And they unto whose Trust the glorious Gospel of the blessed GOD is committed, should be careful to support the Dignity of their Office, which they can do in no such effectual way, as by discharging faith∣fully the Duties belonging to it— And let every Man so account of them, as the Ministers of Christ,
and Stewards of the mysteries of God: and this is to count them worthy of double honour, and to esteem them very highly in Love for their work's sake. That is spoken of, and in the New-Testament is directly ap∣ply'd to the Ministers of the glorious Gospel, which we read in Isa. 52.7. How beautiful upon the moun∣tains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace, that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation, that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth.
2. DOTH the Gospel exceed the Law in Glory? then the Sin of Despising it is very great.

NOTWITHSTANDING the Gospel is so incomparably glorious, yet there are multitudes that despise it. When it was first published to the World, the generality of Men look'd upon it as a very mean or ridiculous Doctrine, and not worthy to be regarded by Ratio∣nal Beings: They called the Preaching of it foolishness. And the most of Men do not entertain a better Opinion of it, at this Day: Some despise it so as to reject the Knowledge of it; they have no desire and take no pains to understand the glorious Truths contained in it. Some are ashamed of the Gospel of CHRIST, asham'd to profess it; and how light do Sinners com∣monly make of the Overtures of Grace therein? All who believe not in CHRIST, and walk not accor∣ding to the Rules of the Gospel, are guilty of despi∣sing it. He that breaks the Law despiseth it, 2 Sam. 12.9. Wherefore hast thou despised the Commandment of the Lord, to do evil in his sight? So all who dis∣obey the Gospel despise it; and the greatness of their Sin and Folly appears from the Glory of the Gospel. The more excellent any thing is, the more vile is the Contempt of it. As much as the Gospel exceeds the Law in Glory, so much worse is it for Men to despise the Gospel than the Law, and exposeth them to so much heavier Punishments. Heb. 10.28, 29. He that despised Moses Law, died without mercy, under two or three witnesses: of how much sorer punishment, suppose ye, shall he be thought worthy, who hath
trodden under foot the Son of God, and hath counted the blood of the Covenant wherewith he was sancti∣fied, and unholy thing, and hath done despite unto the Spirit of Grace? Contempt of the Gospel is treading the Son of GOD underfoot, as if he were really a Worm and no Man, much less GOD: It is setting of him at nought, as truly as Herod with his Men of War did, when they made a mock-King of him: It is trampling the Redeemer's Grace, as if it were nothing worth: And it is counting his pre∣cious Blood, which is the Blood of the Covenant, an unholy, a common thing; such as pollutes rather than purifies the Soul. Despising the Gospel is doing De∣spite unto the Spirit of Grace, the holy Ghost, which accompanies the Gospel to perswade Men of the Truth and Excellency of it, and to make it of saving Efficacy to them. So great is the Sin of Gospel-Contempt that Christ said concerning those who were guilty of despi∣sing the Law and the Prophets, Joh. 16.22 — 24. If I had not come, and spoken unto them, they had not had Sin: but now they have no cloke for their Sin — If I had not done among them the works which none other man did, they had not had Sin: but now they have both seen, and hated both me and my father. The righteous GOD punisheth this Sin with the greatest Judgments, temporal, spiritual and eternal. Wrath came not upon the Jews to the uttermost, un∣til they despised and persecuted the Gospel, Mat. 22.7. When the King heard thereof, he was wroth: and he sent forth his Armies, (the Romans) and destroyed those murderers, and burnt up their City. The sorest outward Calamities are brought on a People, who en∣joy the Gospel, for their Contempt of it. GOD is provoked by Men's despising the Gospel, to smite them with Judicial Blindness, so that they never shall see the Glory of it, Joh. 12.40, 41. They who con∣temptuously shut their Eyes against the light of the Gospel, GOD often Judicially closeth their Eyes, and delivers them to the Power of Satan to blind them, 2 Cor. 4.3, 4. If our Gospel be hid, it is hid to them
that are lost: In whom the God of this world hath blinded the eyes of those that believe not, lest the light of the glorious Gospel of Christ, who is the Image of God, should shine unto them. The Despisers of the Gospel shall be punished with everlasting Destruction: And it will be more tolerable, not only for Sodom and Gomorrah, but also for the Despisers of Moses Law in the Day of Judgment, than for them, 2 Thes. 1.7, 8. The Lord Jesus shall be revealed from Heaven, with his mighty Angels, in flaming fire, taking vengeance on them that know not God, and that obey not the Gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ. — Now consider this, ye that contemn the glorious Gospel, and beware lest that come upon you which is spoken of in the Pro∣phets: Behold, ye despisers, and wonder, and perish.
3. LET what hath been said, raise our Esteem of the Gospel.

THAT which is glorious ought to be valu'd by us, and according to the degree of it's Excellence. The Display of the transcendent Glory of the Gospel shou'd excite and confirm in us a due Esteem of it. — What hath been said concerning the Glory of the Gospel, disparageth not the Law, and will not justify the Con∣tempt of it. The Law is glorious, and deserveth esteem. It was a most suitable Revelation for the People to whom, and the Time wherein it was gran∣ted. Infinite Wisdom judg'd it fit that the discovery of GOD'S Mind & Will concerning the Salvation of fallen Man, shou'd be like the dawning Light, which shineth more and more unto the perfect day. A meri∣dian Brightness was not proper for the Morning of the Church Times. Under the Law the Church was, as it were, in her non-age; and the Instructions GOD gave were suited to her Capacity. Believers were then Children, and the Law was their School-master, to teach them the Elements, the Rudiments, the first Principles of divine Knowledge: Gal. 3.24. The Law was our School-master to bring us unto Christ: It was to prepare the Church for the University of the Gos∣pel,
in which the Knowledge of Christ is more fully taught. GOD vouchsafed further light to his People by extraordinary Prophets which he sent unto them: He at sundry Times, and in diverse manners, spake unto the Fathers by the Prophets, who predicted what the Law prefigur'd, and gave many Promises of the Messiah. Yet it was not perfect day-light until the Sun of Righteousness arose; then the shadows fled away, "and the whole Horizon of heavenly Truth was disclos'd." So that altho' the Law was glorious the divine Revelation before the fulness of Time came was excellent, and to be greatly esteemed, yet the Gos∣pel is far more glorious, and to be more highly va∣lued. The Instructions of the Law were beggarly Ele∣ments, mean Rudiments, in comparison of the deeper and more full Instructions of the Gospel. That is a notable Prophecy concerning the Evangelical Dispen∣sation, Jer. 3.14, 15, 16. I will take you one of a city, and two of a family, and I will bring you to Zion. And I will give you Pastors according to mine heart, which shall feed you with knowledge & under∣standing. And it shall come to pass when ye be mul∣tiplied and increased in the Land; In those days, saith the Lord, they shall say no more, The Ark of the Covenant of the Lord: neither shall it come to mind, neither shall they remember it, neither shall they visit it, neither shall that be done any more. The days of the Messiah are here intended, in which GOD'S People should be fed with Wisdom and Understanding, by faithful evangelical Pastors, in a way different from the Jewish Institution. And their prizing the Gospel Dispensation above the former, is express'd by their not remembring, mentioning, nor visiting the Ark of the Covenant. The Ark was called, The Glory; it was very much the Glory of Israel: It was an eminent Type of Christ, (the Glory of his People;) and a Symbol of GOD'S Presence with his ancient Church. The Old-Testament Saints had it in high account; nothing was more precious unto them: yet it is here foretold, that when Christ, the Antitype of the
Ark, should he come, and a more spiritual Worship erected, then there should be no mention made of the Ark, it should not be remembred, nor come into mind, neither shall that be done any more in it, or, as the Margin renders this, It shall not be magnified any more, It shall not be had in honour or respect, or be made much of. The whole ceremonial Law is not to be valued in comparison of the glorious Gospel; nor the carnal Ordinances of the former, to be men∣tioned in the same day with the spiritual Ordinances of the latter. The moral Law is to be highly esteem'd. GOD will magnify this Law, and make it honourable. It is truly excellent and honourable in it self; and the things of it are great things, and shou'd be so in our account. But the moral Law is only a Revelation of GOD'S Will concerning Man's Duty, not of his Good-Will concerning Man's Sal∣vation. It sheweth us what we ought to do, and con∣demns us for not doing it, and leaves us without hope of escaping it's dreadful Curse. It is a perfect Rule of Obedience, but affords no strength unto impotent Man to walk according to it. Now the Gospel doth not make void the Law, as it is a perfect Rule of Life and Manners, but re-inforceth it, and farther shews how the Sinner may be freed from the Curse, revealing a Righteousness that answers the Demands of the Law, and offers Strength to enable us sincerely & acceptably to keep the divine Precepts. All the intrinsic Glory which the moral Law hath, the Gospel hath, and much more: We should therefore give the Gospel the preference to the Law in our esteem. GOD'S Law was more desired by his Saints than Gold, yea than much fine Gold, It was better to them than Thousands of Gold & Silver. How then ought we to prize the glorious Gospel? It is an inestirnable Pearl we shou'd be willing to part with all things rather than to be with∣out it, Matth. 13.4, 46. The Kingdom of Heaven is like unto a merchant-man, seeking goodly Pearls: who when he had found one Pearl of great price, he went and sold all that he had, and bought it. How
were the ancient Promises valued by those who looked for Redemption? Heb. 11.1 These all died in Faith, not having received Promises (i. e. The Accomplishment of them in the actual Exhibition of the Messiah) but having seen them afar off, and were perswaded of them, and imbraced them. As good old Simeon took up CHRIST in his Arms, so the Patriarchs by Faith imbraced the Promises, "salu∣ted and hugged them," as the original word imports. When they meditated on the Promises, did they not cry out, Oh dear precious Promises that will in time yield the Messiah! How then ought we to value the Gospel, which is the completion of those Promises? Shall we not embrace the glorious Gospel: count it worthy of all acceptation? worthy to be receiv'd with all readiness of Mind, and strength of Affec∣tion.
4. LET us all be solicitous that the Gospel may produce it's glorious Effects in our Souls.

WE have seen that the Gospel is far more glorious than the Law in regard of those wonderful Effects produced by it in the Souls of Men: We should be anxiously concern'd that this Glory of the Gospel be manifested and magnified in our Conversion & Salva∣tion. There must indeed be first a Work of the Law on our Hearts, convincing us of Sin and Wrath, to prepare us for a Work of the Gospel, in Changing our Hearts, and encouraging us to believe in Christ We must seek, that the Commandment may come with power on our Souls, to revive the sense of our Guilt and Misery, and to slay us; to make us see that we are condemned Malefactors, dead in Trespasses and Sins: and then that the Gospel may come unto us in Power, & in the holy Ghost, to give us life. We must look for a saving Change to be wro't in us by the Gospel, as a fit Instrument in the Hand of GOD'S Spi∣rit. The moral Law was never design'd for this use. If ever we be spiritually begotten, it must be thro' the Gospel. The Children of Promise the Heirs
of Salvation are not born of the Bond-woman, Gal. 4.22, &c. All the Terrors on Mount Sinai will not drive a Sinner out of his natural Estate, home unto Christ. There must be a Hope set before him, or he will not fly for Refuge. It is not the sight of GOD'S Glory in the Glass of the Law, but of the Gospel that is transforming. The Glory on the Face of Moses, which was such that the Israelites could not stedfastly behold him, is not sufficient; there must be a discovery of the Glory of GOD in the Face of JESUS CHRIST, in order to a saving Illumi∣nation. The Glory of divine Mercy & Wisdom in our Redemption by CHRIST, must be seen by him that believes in CHRIST, and is transformed into his Image. Let us therefore give earnest heed to the Gospel, as the Instituted ordinary Means of thorow Conversion. Let it be our great Care, vehement De∣sire and constant Prayer, that the Gospel may work effectually in us, as it doth in all them that believe—May be the Power of God unto our Salvation. How sad is it, if we who now speak, and hear so much of the Glory of the Gospel, experience nothing of it's Power on our Hearts, changing of them, and carrying on a Work of Grace in them! How dreadful is it, to have the glorious Gospel prove a savour of Death unto Death! Let us pray that it may come to us, not in Word only, (for then it will eventually be a killing Letter, as well as the Law) but also in power, and in the holy Ghost; that so it's Glory may be exem∣plify'd and display'd in our Salvation.
5. FROM what has been said, Let us be incited to a more diligent Study of the Gospel.

THE Glory of GOD is more fully and clearly re∣veal'd in the Gospel, than it is in the Law: But we cannot see it, nor be affected with it, unless we apply our Minds to the study of the Gospel. The Mysteries of the Gospel afford the most delightful Entertainment to inquisitive Minds. The ancient Prophets, who foretold something of the Glory of the Gospel, us'd
to study their own Prophecies concerning it, 1 Pet. 1.10, 11, 12. Of which Salvation the Prophets have enquired, and searched diligently, who prophesied of the Grace that should come unto you: searching what, or what manner of time the Spirit of Christ which was in them did signify, when it testified before∣hand the sufferings of Christ, and the Glory that should follow: Unto whom it was revealed, that not unto themselves, but unto us they did minister the things which are now reported unto you by them that have preached the Gospel, with the holy Ghost coming down from Heaven, which things the Angels desire to look into. The holy Prophets with great diligence and delight searched into those unfathomable Myste∣ries of Grace, that were in dark Expressions spoken of by themselves, as moved by the Spirit of GOD, and which are more fully and clearly declared in the Gos∣pel: Which Things (saith the Apostle) the Angels desire to look into. This Expression is allusive to the Cherubims which were over the Ark, a Type of Christ, looking down earnestly upon it, as if they would pry into it. The blessed Angels, who behold the Face of GOD in Heaven, do as it were turn their Eyes from viewing his Glory in the upper World, and bend down their sacred Heads to look into the glorious Mysteries of the Gospel. The manifold Wisdom of GOD made known to the Principalities and Powers in heavenly Places, by the Dispensation of his Grace toward the Church, is wonderful and ravishing to them. And shall not we study those things, which the glorious Angels think so worthy their Contemplations? Let us faithfully improve all Means, that are proper and appointed for our Information in the great and impor∣tant Truths of the Gospel. Let us, with the very learned Apostle Paul, Count all things but loss for the Excellency of the Knowledge of Christ Jesus, our Lord. — And as David prayed unto GOD, saying, Open thou mine Eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy Law; so let us pray that GOD
would open our Eyes, that we may behold more won∣drous things out of his Gospel.
6. LET Christians be Exhorted to adorn the glori∣ous Gospel, the Doctrine of God our Saviour in all things.

WE cannot add to the intrinsick Glory of the Gos∣pel, but we should testify and declare it's Excellency by having our Conversation in the World as becometh the Gospel of Christ. It is a Reproach to the glori∣ous Gospel, and brings it into Contempt, when those who profess it walk not according to the holy and ex∣cellent Rules of it, Rom. 2.23, 24. Thou that ma∣kest thy boast of the Law, thro' breaking the Law dishonourest thou God? For the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles thro' you. So when Professors of Christianity disobey the Precepts of it, they darken the Glory of the Gospel, and dishonour the Name of Christ. We receive the Grace of GOD the Gospel in vain, as to our own Souls, unless we conform our Lives to it: as it is shown they had as good have been without the Law, who did not keep it, Jer. 8.8. How do ye say, we are wise, and the Law of the Lord is with us? Lo, certainly in vain made he it, the Pen of the Scribes is in vain. And we render the Gospel unprofitable to others also by our unsuitable Lives: We increase and confirm their Prejudices, which hinder their seeing the Glory of the Gospel.— But the Lustre of a godly Conversation is an Ornament to the glorious Gospel, which we profess. The regular Practice of all the duties which the Gospel requires, sets forth the Glory of the Gospel to best Advantage, and recommends it to those, before whom our Light shineth, and may convince even Infidels that the Gospel came from the GOD of Glory. Christians of the lowest Rank are obliged thus to adorn the Gospel, Tit. 2.9, 10 Let our Conversation therefore be as it becometh the Gospel of Christ, Phil. 1.27. 1 Thes. 2.11, 12. As ye know how we exhorted, and comforted, and
charged every one of you, as a father doth his chil∣dren; That ye would walk worthy of God, who hath called you unto his Kingdom & Glory.
7. LET us be very Thankful to GOD for the Gos∣pel.

WHAT hath been said concerning the Glory of the Gospel (tho' one half hath not been told) may well excite our thankful Praises unto GOD for it. What Advantage had the Jews above the Gentiles? Much every way, chiefly because that unto them were committed the Oracles of God. And Christians have a vast advantage above the Jews, in that the glori∣ous Gospel of the Blessed GOD is committed unto them. GOD hath provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect. The Gospel is a greater Glory unto a People, among whom it is dispensed in the Power & Purity of it, than the Ark was to Israel; and more Glory is due therefor unto GOD from those who enjoy it. How glad would the Patriarchs and Prophets of old have been, to have seen and heard what we do under the Evangelical Dispensation? Matth. 13.16, 17. But blessed are your Eyes, for they see; and your Ears, for they hear: for verily I say unto you, that many Prophets and righteous Men have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them: and to hear those things, which ye hear; and have not heard them. They indeed by the Per∣spective of Faith saw the promised Blessings; but they saw them afar off, had but an obscure View of them to what is now granted. With the Eagle-Eye of Faith Abraham saw the Day of Gospel-light at a great distance, and the remote Prospect which he had of it, made him to rejoice greatly, Joh. 8.56. Your Father Abraham rejoyced to see my day: and he saw it, and was glad. Should not those who live in that day, much more rejoyce in, and be thankful for the Light and Glory of it? GOD'S Peo∣ple devoutly praised him for his distinguish vour
to them, in giving them the Law, Psal. 147.19, 20. He sheweth his word unto Jacob, his statutes and his judgments unto Israel. He hath not dealt so with any nation: And as for his judgments they have not known them. Praise ye the Lord. Should not we much more praise him for sending the glo∣rious Gospel unto us, when so many Nations in the World are as yet destitute of it? Luke 10.21. In that hour Jesus rejoyced in spirit, and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of Heaven and Earth, that thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes: even so, Father, for so it seemed good in thy sight.

DIV1.P: A Pillar of Salt To Season a Corrupt Age. A SERMON TO bring Lot's Wife to Remembrance. Preach'd at the LECTURE in HINGHAM.
By Ebenezer Gay, M. A.

P.HI: I remembred thy Judgments of old, O Lord.
Now all these things happened to them for Ensamples: and they are written for our Ad∣monition upon whom the ends of the world are come.

Q.P: Uxor Loti in salis Statuam conversa fuit, ut nobis quoddam praestaret Condimentum, quo sapiamus aliquid, unde illud caveatur Exemplum.
Poena ejus dat Condimentum Sapientiae Poenitentibus.

DIV1.P: BOSTON: Printed for D. HENCHMAN, 1728

DIV1.HEAD: A Pillar of Salt to Season a corrupt Age.
DIV1.P: OUR Blessed SAVIOUR speaking to his Disciples of the calamitous Destruction which shou'd be brought on Jerusalem, warn'd them to flee out of it, when they shou'd see the Abomination of Desolation standing in the holy Place: i. e. The Roman Ar∣my besieging the City. In the verse immediately pre∣ceding our Text he said, In that day, he which shall be in the house-top, and his staff in the house, let him not come down to take it away: and he that is in the field, let him likewise not turn back: As if he had said, Let every one of my Servants make all possi∣ble haste to get out of Jerusalem, when the Judg∣ments of GOD shall be irresistibly breaking in upon it. And to press this Advice, and excite them to flee with the greatest speed, He added these words, Re∣member Lot's Wife. — And what he said to them, he now saith to us all, whom he is warning to flee from Wrath, Remember Lot's Wife. We should remem∣ber her, not for our Imitation, but for our Admonition and Awakning. — We should remember her Sin, and her Punishment, and may receive much Instruc∣tion and spiritual Profit therefrom.
I. WE shou'd remember the SIN of Lot's Wife.

THIS is recorded, Gen. 19.26. His Wife looked back from behind him. In her flight from Sodom she looked back. But how was this a Sin? Wherein consisted the sinfulness of her so doing? What fault was it for a poor distressed Woman to look back upon the City where she had dwelt, and where her Friends & Acquaintance were, and from whence she was taking her final Departure? Might she not without offence turn her Eyes upon Sodom as she was escaping from it? Might she not see it once more before it was utterly consumed? Might she not cast an Eye of Pity towards, and Weep for her miserable Neighbours in flames of Brimstone?
HER looking back was sinful,
1. BECAUSE it was contrary to a divine Prohibition.

SIN is a Transgression of the Law. Lot's Wive's looking back on Sodom was the Transgression of a particular Law, the breach of an express Order given them, Gen. 19.17. It came to pass when they had brought them forth abroad, that he said, Escape for thy Life, look not behind thee. Lot's Wife, as well as he, was solemnly Charged not to look behind; so that she did that which was expresly and plainly forbidden her. And to act contrary to the least Commandment, or Prohibition of the great GOD, is no small offence, no petty fault. Lot's Wive's Diso∣bedience may be illustrated by that of Saul's, in spa∣ring the best of the Amalekites Sheep and Oxen for Sacrifice; This was very offensive to GOD, because contrary to an express Order given him to slay them all: The Prophet thus set his Sin before him, 1 Sam. 15, 22, 23. Hath the Lord as great delight in burnt-offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the Lord? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of Rams. For rebellion is as the of witchcraft, and stubbornness it is as iniquity and idolatry. Saul's rebellion in that matter, which was in it self small, was as really a Sin, & Provocation
of GOD'S Wrath as Witchcraft or Idolatry. It was a Contempt of the great Lawgiver's Authority. And so was Lot's Wive's looking back. Abraham the same Morning looked toward Sodom, and saw the smoke of it's Torments ascending, Gen. 19.27, 28. This was no Sin in Abraham, for he was not for∣bidden to look toward Sodom: But it was a great Sin in Lot's Wife to look back upon it, for the Lord had said to her, Look not behind thee.

THIS teacheth us, to measure Sin by the Command∣ment; and so it will appear exceeding sinful. Persons are ready to make light of many evil Actions, and to stroke them with a gentle Censure, because they are not so gross & crying as others. But the matter in which we Sin is not so much to be regarded, as the Authority which is thereby despised. What is in it self small & inconsi∣derable is a great offence, if the Lord hath forbidden it. The first Woman took of the fruit of a certain Tree in Eden, and eat it. Could so small a thing as the eat∣ing an Apple be very offensive to GOD? Yet the Lord God said unto the Woman, What is this thou hast done? Gen. 3.13. What an heinous Crime hast thou committed? Because GOD had expresly said, Of that Tree thou shalt not eat. GOD'S Authority is con∣temned, his Will resisted by our doing the least thing which he hath forbidden; therefore no such Act must be accounted by us a small offence. We should not say of it, as Lot did of Zoar, which he desir'd might be spared to be the City of his Refuge, Is it not a little One? Sometimes the smaller the matter is in which we transgress, the greater is the Offence; as when the Prohibition of it is very plain & peremp∣tory, the Temptation unto it slight, and it be a thing which might easily be left undone. Whatsoever we do contrary to the declared Will of GOD, is a horrid In∣dignity offer'd to his Majesty & Authority: It is Re∣bellion, which in every case is as the Sin of Witchcraft and Idolatry.
2. IN Lot's Wive's looking back upon Sodom there was a Contempt of GOD's Omniscience.

SHE not only despis'd the Authority & Com∣mandment
of GOD, but also practically deny'd his Omniscience: for it is said, that she locked back from behind Lot. She committed this Sin secretly. She was behind her Husband; and since his Eye was not upon her, she ventur'd to look back; thereby expres∣sing a Contempt of GOD'S all-seeing Eye. She was afraid that if righteous Lot saw her he wou'd be angry with her for disobeying the Lord; but not afraid that a Righteous GOD would see her, and be displea∣sed at her Sin. This is an aggravation of secret Sins, that the Omniscience of GOD is especially contemned thereby; as if the Eye of GOD was not to be so much regarded & reverenc'd as the Eye of Man.
3. LOT's Wive's looking back on Sodom procee∣ded from an evil Heart of Unbelief.

THE Angels which came to Lot's House, told him, and his Wife, that swift Destruction was coming upon Sodom: Lot inform'd his Sons in-law of it, and said unto them, Up, get ye out of this place, for the Lord will destroy this city: but he seemed unto them as one that mocked. Altho' his Wife did not reject the Warning with such scorn, as they did, yet it seems, that she question'd the Truth of the Threatning, and therefore look'd back to see whether it would be Executed or not. It was said to her, Look not behind thee, lest thou be consumed. But she did not believe she shou'd be consumed for looking back. It is said in the Book of the Wisdom of Solomon, chap. 10. v. 7. That a standing Pillar of Salt, is a Monument of an unbelieving Soul.—Not to believe GOD, is to make him a Liar: It is a great Sin, to doubt of his Veracity in his Menaces, as well as Promises. Such Unbelief is the Root of Disobedience. Men despise the Com∣mandments of GOD, because they do not believe his Threatnings, Heb. 3.12. Take heed, Brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, in de∣parting from the living God.
4. THERE was the Lust of the Eye in Lot's Wive's looking back upon Sodom.

"IT was a look of Covetousness". Sodom was a rich and pleasant place: It was even as the Garden of
the Lord, Gen. 13.10. Lot's Wife was very loth to go out of it; she lingered in it, (as indeed Lot himself did) after she was warned to flee; the An∣gels laid hold on her hand, and brought her forth, and set her without the City, plucking her as a Brand out of the Fire: and she went not far from Sodom before her Love to her worldly accommodations there, made her look back, with uneasy Desires to return to it, there to enjoy the Wealth, Pleasures & Friends which she had left. So that her Sin was great: her Rebellion was as the Sin of Idolatry, for Covetousness is Idolatry: It is loving and serving the Crea∣ture more than the Creator. We cannot obey GOD, so long as this Lust remains unmortified: We may seem to hearken to his Call for a time, and to flee from Wrath; but if we love the World, and the things of it, we shall look, and draw back unto Perdition, 2 Tim. 4.10. Demas hath forsaken me, having lo∣ved this present World. We should remember Lot's Wife, that we may take heed and beware of Cove∣tousness.
5. LOT's Wive's looking back on Sodom imply'd a Contempt of the Mercy of GOD in delivering her out of it.

WHEN the Lord was about to rain "Hell out of Heaven" upon Sodom, and the Neighbouring Cities, he sent his Angels (and one of them was the blessed Angel of the Covenant, for he is stiled Jehovah, Gen. 19.24.) GOD sent them to bring out Lot, and his Wife and Children, that they might not be consumed in the Iniquity & Overthrow of Sodom. The Lord being merciful did this: Lot spake of it with Admiration, say∣ing, Behold now, thy Servant hath found Grace in thy sight, and thou hast magnified thy mercy which thou hast shewed unto me in saving my Life. But his Wife despised so great a Mercy; she had low Thot's of it: she did not accept the miraculous Deliverance with Thankfulness: she was so unsuitably affected with the Kindness GOD had shown her in saving her Life, that she look'd back on Sodom with a discontented Eye, be∣cause she was from her worldly Enjoyments there.
